Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: It was a slow afternoon at the grocery store, and I stood behind the register, scanning items for the handful of customers trickling in. My manager expected me to be precise, to keep the line moving and the till balanced. I glanced at the clock—4:45 p.m. The main weekly service at the church started in fifteen minutes, and as the priest, I was supposed to lead the prayers and offer comfort to my congregation. My phone buzzed in my pocket: a reminder from the church secretary, “Everyone’s gathering now.” I looked at the growing line, a mother with a restless toddler, an elderly man counting coins. I felt the weight of both uniforms—the apron and the collar—pressing on my chest. The store needed me to stay, to finish my shift, but my community needed me at the altar. My hands trembled as I handed back change, my mind torn between the beep of the scanner and the echo of hymns waiting to be sung.
